title: Will Verizon and Yahoo conclude their merger before 1 June 2017?
possible_answers: Yes, for a price of less than $4.8258 billion
Yes, for a price of $4.8258 billion
Yes, for a price more than $4.8258 billion
preds: Special meeting with shareholders on 8 June.  They will not close before then.

The deal is scheduled to be completed in mid June.  Some updates: Yahoo Is Buying Back $3 Billion Shares - Fortune-May 16, 2017
"Yahoo said on Tuesday it would buy back $3 billion of its common shares, ahead of the company's pending deal with Verizon Communications." "Verizon To Launch An OTT Service After Yahoo Acquisition" - May 23, 2017 - Written By Dominik Bosnjak
Verizon Wireless is looking to launch an over-the-top (OTT) content delivery service following its acquisition of Yahoo, according to Lowell McAdam, CEO. McAdam reiterated Verizon’s plans to merge Yahoo’s core business with its AOL division into a new unit called Oath, adding that the consolidated firm’s platform will be used to launch an experimental version of a new OTT service. 
https://www.androidheadlines.com/2017/05/verizon-launch-ott-service-yahoo-acquisition.html Martha Nelson to exit as Yahoo’s top editor amid merger
http://nypost.com/2017/05/16/martha-nelson-to-exit-as-yahoos-top-editor-amid-merger/
Everything I'm reading indicates that the deal will conclude in June, before the end of the second quarter. The 10% hedge is due to the possibility that further discounts could hasten the merger.
Company announcements that the deal will close in June (not before June 1).

This is going to happen. Probably not before June 1, 2017. Initially Yahoo which would seem to be the most interested in completing the deal had a longer timeline than Verizon. Timelines are almost always missed when dealing with such large complex systems. The 15% chance the deal happens before June 1 is due to how much Verizon may actually need Yahoo despite the issue with user data breeches. If Verizon is at risk of not maintaining the impressive dividend growth and the Yahoo acquisition prevents this stagnation a deal may be reached before June 1 but certainly for less than $4.8258 billion as a $350 million dollar discount has already been agreed to.
This deal will probably not happen in the next weeks, But Yahoo has been on downfall for a while now. I do know the deal will occur, but not this fast after the start of Yahoo's year.
A vote on the deal is not planned until after June 1.
Wait till the end of Q2 at least.

Why I don't think it will close by 6/1
1) Regulatory uncertainty presents risks to deal timeline; companies don't want to be sued by the gov't(s)
2) May 9, 2017 statements from Verizon CEO re: urgency to do mega-deal; he could be posturing
3) Rumors of other potential suitors, such as Comcast and Disney, could be fueled by recent poor earnings release
4) Value of Yahoo's assets continue to decline Why it could happen...
1) Deal has been widely reported as probable since July 2016.
2) Price of $4.4 billion has been reported since April 19, after Yahoo's Q1 earnings beat; reduced by $350 million in Feb 2017 in connection with user data breach.
3) Many stakeholders have short-term incentives (shares, options) to make a deal happen.

Yahoo and its properties are simply not worth that much in the market. It has long since been an afterthought in search and increasingly in many other spaces. It has value as a pioneer but not much in true market value, outside of decent fantasy sports and Alibaba, they are trapped. Forced between taking a massive tax hit on a large windfall on one of their most beneficial investments in over a decade or letting it go to Verizon which weakens the US market as major ISPs seek to consolidate major resources. However if Trump get his tax plan passed, expect major consolidation or concentration in markets as the big seek to get bigger to reap the windfalls of the lopsided tax policy.

According to the below article (feels self referential to use a Yahoo article about the Yahoo Verizon merger) the merger will be completed in June. https://finance.yahoo.com/news/yahoo-yhoo-posts-q1-earnings-221210693.html
Per Rene, vote won't happen until June 8.
average merger 10 months, add at least 3 months for cybersecurity issues
It is very hard to think about this question without being reminded of the Yahoos in Gulliver's Travels.

A vote on the deal is not planned until after June 1.  However, like most M&A deals, roadblocks for this one can be solved with money.  So if the two companies wanted to conclude the merger sooner they could but it would be at a lower price.

The Yahoo-Verizon merger may have hit a few roadblocks on the way but the transaction is nearing a closure. With its $4.48 billion acquisition by the telecom giant, one of the most renowned Internet giants would officially cease to exist. Yahoo’s shareholders are mostly expected to vote in favor of the buyout of the company’s core assets, through a voting process scheduled for June 8.
https://thetechportal.com/2017/04/26/yahoo-marissa-mayer-exit-huge-payout/ Question asks for 1 June.
Looks like final Yahoo vote is scheduled for June 8th.

I missed this earlier: the vote won't happen until June 8:
http://www.cnbc.com/2017/04/25/marissa-mayer-will-make-186-million-on-yahoos-sale-to-verizon.html
Not before June 8, when Yahoo shareholders vote.

"SAN FRANCISCO — Yahoo shareholders will vote June 8 on whether to sell the company’s internet businesses to Verizon Communications for $4.48 billion." https://www.nytimes.com/2017/04/24/technology/marissa-mayer-will-make-186-million-on-yahoos-sale-to-verizon.html?_r=0
The deadline looms, and apparently there is still paperwork to be tidied up.  And as we all know, it doesn't matter what's true. It only matters what the paperwork says.
@seamusfag 's link says Mayer doesn't expect to be out of a job until the deal is completed "in June."  Almost all of June comes after the 1st....

Yahoo chief Marissa Mayer will quit the company's board after the merger with Verizon that creates Oath, according to an SEC filing, though she is expected to remain with the core Yahoo business.
"As we enter our final quarter as an independent company, we are committed to finishing strong and planning for the best possible integration with Verizon," Mayer said in the earnings release.
"With the transaction anticipated to complete in June, I've never been more proud of the improvements we've made to the business." https://phys.org/news/2017-04-yahoo-cusp-verizon-merger.html
With the latest revelation they will go below the original asking price.

The Yahoo-Verizon deal is supposed to close in the second quarter of 2017, perhaps on or before April 24. After April 24, the parties can seek a three-month extension, but there’s also an opening for either party to terminate the deal.
https://www.businessinsider.com.au/aol-and-yahoo-will-become-oath-after-merger-closes-2017-4?r=US&IR=T
Anyone know why this hasn't been in the news recently? It should be happening soon but I haven't heard anything.

Increasing because I can't imagine bonds would be issued and paid for and then the cash not used for the described purpose within three months:  http://www.nasdaq.com/article/verizon-raises-us11bn-for-yahoo-buy-and-bond-buyback-20170317-00522 .
Everybody merging these days. All hail the pluralopoly.

Yahoo's data breaches have raised great concern to Verizon.  Fourth quarter earnings have drove Verizon to negotiate a $350 million drop in price.  In addition, no timeline for the acquisition has been proposed.  As it stands now, the price is likely to be negotiated somewhere between 4.8258 billion and 4.475 billion.  This suggests that a feasible negotiating price would be near 4.5627 billion after meeting in the middle two times.  This price is not more than 4.8258 billion nor is it even near that number.  For that reason I would conclude a 0% chance of a higher price or equal price.  The data breaches and fourth quarter earnings bring up a no-deal scenario, which is possible.  However, with the AT&T/Direct TV merger for $67 billion, it seems there is very aggressive acquisition behavior in the telecommunications industry.  I conclude 20% no deal, 80% less than 4.8258 billion.

Supposedly there will be federal charges related to the Yahoo hacking:
https://www.wsj.com/articles/u-s-officials-plan-to-unveil-charges-tied-to-yahoo-hack-1489542870
According to my corporate finance notes: "vast majority of announced deals close"
So question is certainly will these federal charges hold-up the closing??  They can't help so I'm downgrading my confidence some...
Keep an eye on this, as it could be after June 1 but before June 30.
It is overwhelmingly likely that the deal will now go through at the revised price of 4.48 billion agreed in February. Unless Yahoo is still hiding some other even crazier data breach.
Adapting to the information given by the main media
http://www.reuters.com/article/us-yahoo-m-a-verizon-idUSKBN1601EK Price is set, so only the Yes/No part remains.

https://www.nytimes.com/2017/02/15/business/dealbook/verizon-yahoo-merger-deal.html I don't think the question is about the price, I think it is about whether the deal will close before 1 June 2017. Will spend the next few days thinking about this.
Deal is supposed to close in the 2nd quarter, i.e. may slip behind the June 1st due date set in the GJO question.
They have made announcement that it will happen at a 350 mil discount. There's always a possibility another issue may arise.
Price agreed is $4.48 billion. Timing may be an issue. Merger has to be done by June 30, not June 1.

Recent release (http://www.verizon.com/about/news/verizon-and-yahoo-amend-terms-definitive-agreement) strengthens my original stance. The question remains if this will happen within June ( after the question deadline of 6/1 but within management's guidance of "within 2nd quarter 2017".

Corporate deadline seems to be June 30th.
From: http://www.bbc.com/news/business-39037198:
Marni Walden, Verizon executive vice president said: "The amended terms of the agreement provide a fair and favourable outcome for shareholders. It provides protections for both sides and delivers a clear path to close the transaction in the second quarter."

New agreemend announced including lower sales price.  Options are now between close for less than 4.8258 or close after June 1st.  "Hopeful" timeline is "no sooner than April 1st".
Critical hurdles remaining:
SEC prob of Yahoo is underway and will need to be closer prior to Yahoo shareholder vote on proxy statement
SEC probe timelines are not apparent.  Case seems similar to Target case which was dismissed except the timing of announcement and the breach is substantially longer.  People are saying SEC may use Yahoo as a test-case concerning data-breeches which seems like it would only extend their diligence.
Management likely has some clue as to expected SEC timing and if given SEC and proxy timing will push closing as close to their goal as possible.
Unknowns:
Chance SEC closes in time: 50%
Given SEC in time Chance shareholders approve proxy: 95%
Given approval is timely chance closing is executed in time: 90%
Or- Chance management is right: 60%
Late to the party but following @rene @clinton @resonancia and all of the recent comments with links.
https://www.bloomberg.com/news/videos/2017-02-16/verizon-said-to-be-close-to-revised-yahoo-deal?cmpid=yhoo.headline&yptr=yahoo Yahoo might still want to negotiate and deadline will be passed.

Verizon Communications Inc (VZ.N) is close to a revised deal to buy Yahoo Inc's (YHOO.O) core internet business for $250 million to $350 million less than the original agreed price of $4.83 billion, according to a source briefed on the matter.
http://www.reuters.com/article/us-yahoo-m-a-verizon-idUSKBN15U21R

Updating based on Bloomberg ( reliable finance rumor source ) here: https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-02-15/verizon-reduces-yahoo-deal-price-by-250-million-in-revised-deal . Leaving a 5% chance that Yahoo is hiding yet still more issues that will come to light in the final weeks of closing the deal.  It must be tough to keep the engineering force (including sec ops) of a former silicon valley heavyweight excited to work hard to push through a deal with Verizon ( known as the "dumb pipe" back in the day ).

Deal will no close for more than original 4.8258 price
SEC case is pending and will need to be closed prior to shareholder vote
"April is possible"
Investigation could still reveal more issues
Verizon's recent earnings announcement makes clear that they still need the deal to help with growth. But, not likely to pay up for it. Thus, adjusting down my price expectations.

Yahoo is desperate to sale and Verizon desperately needs an audience on the web. Yahoo will have to sell at a substantial discount which is more probable than not. There is some minimal chance that Yahoo will hold and try to rebuild their reputation and brand in order to be as close as possible to the original 4.8258 sales price.

VZ considers the media part of YHOO to be essential technology for marketing distribution globally. Still, this is not enough to justify such price tag. I am been generous and give a 1/10 provability to get the asking price, but I doubt that the financing will justify such price tag. Now, when cheap money reigns prices can get distorted!
A cancellation of the merger would be seen as failure for both managements, while a closed deal at a lower price would be considered good management from both companies.

Verizon's shareholders will require a discount in light of the information on data breach.
The original reasons for the merger might not hold true anymore, hence the 30% for a No.

1) I assume Verizon shareholders would be upset if they did not get a discount given the massive data breach. 2) Yahoo is a declining tech asset that I believe has not had many offers ( apologies, would like ref here for proof ). 3) Verizon still thinks they can monetize a larger audience, which is their original reason for wanting to buy Yahoo. 
https://www.wsj.com/articles/why-verizon-wants-yahoo-1477879861

Verizon Settlement Approved by New York Court
https://easterndaily.com/verizon-settlement-approved-new-york/
Still a strategic rationale for the merger and stronger earnings help alleviate concerns over hacking breaches.
Still think Verizon need to get this done so price will stay the same
I am interested in the merger.
Apple was run to ground and revived under Steve Jobs' return.   No good prediction should completely discount the "Return of the Jedi" miracle.
Yahoo share price holding up and Verizon missed earnings so Verizon probably need this to happen, time frame now second quarter so a month of this falls after 1st June
Adjusting toward consensus. I may be overestimating a Yes answer.

Second security breach could be evidence of systemic problem and further degredation of revenue
Verizon could claim misrepresentation
Verizon also pursuing deal with charter cable could further complicate closing date
all of above make higher price unlikely and lean toward late or not closing
Some earnings disappointment plus increased security liabilities risk.  Given complexity in general re markets a bias towards a longer time to completion is reasonable.

Yahoo's recently disclosed security breaches are likely to reduce Verizon's valuation of it, and increase pressure for acceptance of a lower terminal bid. If Yahoo can't sufficiently devalue itself, this may result in a failed merger.
adapting to the new information about the delayed contract

http://www.reuters.com/article/us-yahoo-results-idUSKBN1572PM
http://www.reuters.com/article/us-verizon-results-idUSKBN1581GM?il=0 Let's see--a market leader with shrinking revenues will buy a search engine with weak security and in a declining industry segment besides.  What could possibly go wrong?

If Meyer couldn't run Yahoo right how can she and her team fix its security problems. The fix should be Ma Verizon's and the price should be lower, with the probability that perennial loss leader Yahoo is left at the alter.  See link http://nypost.com/2017/01/23/yahoo-delays-merger-with-verizon-over-hacking/

Delayed closing "no sooner than April" announced today, with no new due date
https://www.nytimes.com/2017/01/23/technology/yahoo-verizon-sale-delayed.html?pagewanted=all
and SEC probe indicated by WSJ 
http://www.wsj.com/articles/yahoo-faces-sec-probe-over-data-breaches-1485133124

Yahoo said Monday that the closing of a $4.8 billion deal to sell its core internet assets to US telecom titan Verizon has been delayed several months. 
https://phys.org/news/2017-01-sale-core-yahoo-assets-verizon.html Looking less and less likely.
VZ moving deal back to April: http://www.wsj.com/articles/yahoo-sees-verizon-deal-taking-longer-than-expected-1485206759?mod=e2fb
Delays have a way of multiplying.

I think Verizon wants the deal. Now is the question if the US regulatory will allow the deal if the investigations are on the go. Moreover i think Verizon will lower the price due to the fact that a second leak occured.
Yahoo doesn't look like they were honest in their disclosures to potential bidders.  What a shame for Yahoo investors.

Verizon wants the deal. They might be foreseeing risks of commoditization of the core business and the rationale for the merger is preemptive to preserve competitive positioning. Competitor AT&T has acquired Direct TV and Comcast acquired NBC/Universal adding to the motivation to get the deal done. AOL, whom Verizon now owns, attempted while it was an independent company to merge with Yahoo in 2013. Now Verizon, still seeing the logic of that deal, has the opportunity to make it happen at a better price. No court in Delaware, where Yahoo is incorporated, has ever found that a material adverse effect has occurred that would allow companies to terminate a merger agreement and although there may be more damage that is latent and yet to become visible, the breach, albeit only recently reported, took place in 2014 which has allowed time for major damage to cash flows resulting from the data breach to materialize in Yahoo's financials. Lastly, there will be a renegotiation and although a price concession is the easiest form of renegotiation, due to the nature of the problem, a price concession seems less likely than a delay and/or clawback/indemnification provision. Nevertheless, regarding the price concession there is reputation to consider and given Verizon's strong position in the negotiation they will likely require some win on price to preserve reputation and this is why I believe that the deal will close but at a lower than sticker price.
Merges between operators and internet firms are absolutely likely given actual and forecasted market trends.

Altaba has no reason to continue its association with the liabilities of Yahoo, thus is in a position to be induced to knock a few million off the sales price. Goodwill, after all, was substantially impaired by the hack. I haven't looked at Yahoo's balance sheet for a while, but would be surprised if that hadn't been a substantial "asset." In the meantime, Verizon wants the ad technology and is already dealing with Yahoo e-mail accounts. In for a penny, in for a pound. Once the Europeans gave approval, the only question was final price.

The European Commission on Wednesday gave its nod of approval to Verizon’s proposed acquisition of Yahoo 
https://www.wirelessweek.com/news/2016/12/eu-approves-verizons-yahoo-acquisition-questions-about-deals-fate-still-remain Why Verizon probably won't back out of the Yahoo deal
http://www.cnbc.com/2017/01/06/why-verizon-probably-wont-back-out-of-the-yahoo-deal.html
Agree with the delayed merger comment.
Some information will come out beforehand that will delay the merger.
Subject to Trump's ire, but aside from routine hack used as leverage to get a better deal, no indication of deal not going forward. Low confidence as a result of time window.
Even a Republican Government unlikely to look kindly on such a large merger. Valuation however more likely to go down than up.

Verizon needs this deal but they will try to negotiate a better price. Major hacking scandals are a routine part of the business landscape and companies do survive it. Yahoo’s hacking scandal will fade away and the deal will be done.
